data.text: Contents
The Uk CAA Elevated Helideck RFFS Requirement .................................................. 14
Introduction

The Manual and Standard Operating Procedures describe the physical characteristics of the helideck and RFFS facilities that are essential for the safe operation of helicopters arriving and departing the helideck.

Particular attention is given to the Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) that have been devised for safe and effective operation of the helideck in accordance with ICAO Annex 14 – Heliports; CAP 789 (Requirements and Guidance Material for Operators).

The Broomfield Hospital helideck operates by best practice to 'Permanently Unlicensed H1 Elevated Helideck' standards in accordance with CAP 789 and as such, is not subject to formal licensed helipad inspections by the CAA.

As an un-licensed helicopter landing site the helicopter operators using the facility have the responsibility to inspect and ensure that the Broomfield Hospital Helideck conforms fully to ICAO Annex  and CAP 789 standards.
The Standard Operating Procedures sections describe the daily procedures Broomfield Hospital helideck staff will carry out to prepare the helideck operationally and during helicopter operations.

In addition the Manual and Standard Operations Procedures identify the key persons and helideck emergency response staff involved in the management and operation of the helideck stating their positions, duties, responsibilities and to whom they are accountable.

This Manual and Standard Operations Procedures are a ‘living document' and as such will be subject to periodic reviews and amendments as may be required, to reflect changes in the operation, facilities or physical characteristics of the helideck or changes to regulations which are applicable to the helideck.
This Manual and Standard Operations Procedures was originally prepared and written by Jim Seager (Helicopter Support Services) on request of the Broomfield Hospital.
Policy Statement

1.9.1 The  Broomfield  Hospital  Helideck  will  provide  a  Helicopter  Emergency  Medical Service (HEMS) daylight only landing facility Monday-Friday between the hours of 0800–1600 or darkness (official darkness is defined as  minutes before sunrise or after sunset).

1.9.2 This helideck facility is only available for the specific use of HEMS providers, Police Air Services and armed forces helicopters being used in a HEMS role capacity operating to H1 standards with Category A, Class 1 performance.

1.9.3 An RFFS response team will be provided by MEHT consisting of whole time Fire Fighters & trained ‘volunteer' staff employed by the Trust to crew the helideck during all helicopter movements, as required by, and in accordance with International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) and Civil Aviation Authority UK legislation. A minimum of two fully trained, competent fire fighters to at least CAA Lower Category Aerodrome and Helipad standards must be made available for all helicopter movements to and from the Broomfield Hospital helideck.
1.9.4 A CAA training syllabus for heliport RFF personnel is provided in CAP789 Appendix A to Annex
1.9.5 All training and instruction must only be carried out by competent and qualified instructors.
1.9.6 Whole-time staff shortages will be covered by a fully trained and competent fire officer/fighter enrolled on the Broomfield Bank staff Health Roster.

1.9.7 Where the required trained and competent staffing levels cannot be provided or maintained the helideck must be declared closed for all helicopter movements until such time remedial actions are implemented to resolve the situation.
1.9.8 Where the masculine term ‘he' is used within this and all other helideck documents, it also applies to the feminine ‘she'.
1.9.9 The Helideck Standard Operations Procedures is a controlled document and a numbered copy may only be issued to each of the following recipients: -
a) Helicopter Operations
b) Essex County F&RS
c) East of England Ambulance Service Critical Care Desk
1.9.10 This Helideck Standard Operations Procedures and the Helideck Risk Assessments will be subject to annual review.
1.9.11 Declaration of Modem Operandi: The standards that the helideck is operating to are those detailed in CAP789 - Requirements and Guidance Material for Operators:
Note: Where these standards are deviated from, the justification and level to which the deviation is applied are appropriately documented in the ‘CAP437 & CAP789' folder in the Helideck Office.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

The purpose and scope of this Manual and Standard Operations Procedures is to show how the Broomfield and Hospital Management will discharge their responsibilities in the safe and efficient operation of the Broomfield Hospital Helideck.
Definitions

table_items.text: CAP 393 - Air Navigation Order. The Orders and Regulations 2014
The part of an airport/heliport directly involved in the arrival and departure of aircraft and from which point security measures are put in place.
East of England Ambulance Service Critical Care Desk

The largest overall dimension of the helicopter when rotors are turning. This dimension will normally be measured from the most forward position of the main rotor tip to the most rearward position of the tail rotor tip or the most rearward extension of the fuselage in the case of Fenestron or NOTAR helicopters.
Essex County Fire and Rescue Services
Final Approach and Take Off area

A generic term referring to the load-bearing area primarily intended for the landing and take-off of aircraft. The area, sometimes referred to as the Final Approach and Take-Off area (FATO), is bounded by the perimeter line and perimeter lighting.
Touchdown/Positioning Marking Circle is the aiming point for a normal landing

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Fire Safety Group

On behalf of the Trust's Health & Safety Management Group, the Fire Safety Group will act and be recognised for all statutory and regulatory purposes as the Group responsible for Fire Safety within the Trust and shall scrutinise or investigate any areas covered within its Terms of Reference as agreed by the Board.

It may seek internal and external information and all employees are directed to co- operate.  The  Group  may  seek  outside  external  or  otherwise  independent professional advice and legal opinion.
The Helideck Manager
Reporting to:
Chief Operations Officer
Executive Director (Estates and Facilities)
Liaise with:
Trust Senior Hospital Fire Officer on fire safety issues.
Purpose of Job:

Overall responsibility to manage all staff employed within the Helideck Fire & rescue Service to maintain an immediate and efficient landing facility for the Helicopter Emergency Medical Services wishing to use the Broomfield Hospital Helideck and to ensure that there are means to provide an immediate response to any Helideck related emergency.
Helideck Fire Officer
Reporting to:
Helideck Manager
Executive Director (Estates and Facilities)
Liaise with:
Trust Senior Hospital Fire Officer on fire safety issues.
Purpose of Job:
To be in operational command of a watch and provide an immediate and efficient response to any helideck related emergency.
To provide, by extraneous duties, an effective RFFS helideck operation and to be available to provide an advisory service for local authority fire services.
General Responsibilities:

The Helideck Fire Officer/Lead Helideck Fire Fighter are responsible for the safety and welfare of the duty watch. They are to ensure that there is a safe and efficient operating environment. This will be achieved through the effective management of the duty watch and with close liaison with all other helideck agencies and operatives.
Lead Helideck Fire Fighter /Helideck Fire Fighter
Reporting to:
Helideck Fire Officer/Lead Helideck Fire Fighter
Helideck Manager Purpose of Job:
To provide as part of a watch an immediate and efficient response to any helideck related emergency.
General Responsibilities:
To provide as a member of a team, by extraneous duties, an effective helideck operation and to be available to provide an advisory service for local authority fire services.
Safety Accountabilities and Duties (non-prescriptive)
They are to ensure that any deficiency in PPE is reported immediately to the Helideck Manager.
They are to be aware of all safety requirements needed in a helideck operation.
They are to ensure that all equipment is operated in a safe and competent manner as trained.
They are to ensure that they are physically fit to perform the range of duties commensurate with their employment and they are to ensure that they are current to all mandatory medical requirements.
They must ensure that they are familiar with the contents of the Helideck Standard Operations Policy
To adhere and comply with all matters on the Helideck concerning the Health & Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 and the Management of Health & Safety at Work Regulations1999.
To operate effectively all firefighting equipment and to report and record any deficiencies to the Helideck Manager
To respond to all Helideck emergencies as part of a duty watch.
To ensure that they are competent in the operation of all associated helideck equipment including helideck lighting.
To ensure that documentation for all activities is completed immediately on completion of task.
Ensure that all tests and inspections of specialised equipment are carried out as laid down in CAA Regulated Documents, Fire Service Drill Book or manufacturers hand book.
Perform snow-clearing duties as and when required.
Carry out safety and surface inspections when required.
Be proficient in the administration of Emergency First Aid and render First Aid when required.
Visual security checking of helicopter panels, doors, passenger safety helmets and straps before helicopter departures.
Calling and locking off the helideck lift.
Preparation of the medical trolley and medical equipment as trained for.
Cleaning specified medical equipment between missions .
Supervision of patient off-loading as appropriate and trained.
Restock Oxygen Cylinders if requested.
Escorting the medical team and patient to the hospital trauma lift and to the appropriate receiving department.
Communicate any Deficiencies to other Helideck Crew Members
The Helideck Lines Of Responsibility
Trust Chief Executive Officer
Chief Estates & Facilities Officer
The Helideck Operations Manager
& Head of Fire Safety
The Trust Fire Safety  Lead Helideck Fire
Officer  Fighter
Helideck Fire Fighter Volunteers (including Fire Safety Team Members)
The Uk CAA Elevated Helideck RFFS Requirement

The Broomfield Hospital helideck requires a competent aviation rescue and fire fighting (RFF) facility to be readily available to attend all helicopter arrivals and departures in accordance with UK Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) legislation.

The daily duty helideck fire crew shall comprise a minimum of one whole time Helideck Fire Officer/Lead Helideck Fire Fighter and one Helideck Fire Fighter who must be fully trained, current and competent.

It is a UK CAA requirement that all persons actively involved in aviation fire fighting and rescue duties shall receive pre-planned, structured learning programmes for initial and continuous on-going training, including regular realistic hot fire training.

Each fire fighter shall receive appropriate training to standards laid down in CAP 789, Chapter 21, Appendix 3 and from adaptations of CAP 699 ‘Standards for the Competence of Rescue and Fire Fighting Service (RFFS) Personnel' amended as appropriate to suit the operational requirements of the Broomfield helideck.

Before any whole time or Volunteer Fire Fighter is allowed to work on or around the helideck they must prove competent in the practical use and technical knowledge of all the firefighting systems and equipment available on the helideck and demonstrate their practical methods of operation. This will also form part of an on- going training programme and assessment.

All Helideck Fire Fighters will be required to undertake a Three-day Helideck Fire Training Course delivered by a Qualified and Competent Person / Organisation then as advised by Auditor (section 3.2) and successfully pass written and practical exams before being passed ‘competent in acquisition' with skills and knowledge to be part of the helideck response team.

Each member of the helideck fire crew will be continually assessed to ensure they meet the appropriate level of competencies required to crew the Broomfield helideck in accordance with the Broomfield Helideck Training Manual.

Realistic hot fire training exercises will be held at an accredited site at six monthly intervals as laid down in the Broomfield Helideck Training Manual. The Senior Helideck Fire Officer/Lead Helideck Fire Fighter / Helideck Manager shall be responsible for arranging and booking all training.
Two types of certificate will be issued to successful helideck fire fighters depending on their achieved levels of competence.

Certificate in Acquisition – This certificate will be issued to individuals on successful completion of the initial course work and only when they are able to demonstrate that they can apply the learning acquired in the workplace to the standards defined in the performance criteria for their role, but further training and experience is required to achieve full competency.

Certificate of Competence – A Certificate of Competence will be issued to individuals as evidence that the individual has satisfied the relevant standards in acquisition and application and performed consistently over a period of a minimum of twelve months and after attending at least two accredited hot fire training sites.
No fire fighter will be allowed to work on the helideck un-supervised unless in procession of a current Certificate of Competence.
Certificates of Competence will be valid for 3 years or unless revoked for whatever reason.

It is a Health & Safety Executive (HSE) requirement that all fire fighters shall be physically and medically fit to meet the requirements of the task to the standard required by Broomfield. This will be managed by the Broomfield Occupational Health Department.
All  members  of  the  helideck  fire  response  team  will  be  required  to  familiarise themselves with the following manuals, copies of which will be kept in the Helideck Office.
Helideck Standard Operational Procedures
Control of Substances Hazardous to Health (COSHH) (Helideck)
Clinical Operational Policy
Major Incident Policy
Internal Incident Policy
CBRN/HAZMAT Incident Plan

5.21.4 Wet Riser Inlet

The Wet Riser Inlet for Local Fire & Rescue Services to supplement the Helideck Primary Fire Fighting Systems is located at ground level below the Helideck South Standby Point at the exit to the ambulance/A&E access road.
5.21.5 Fire Service Hydrants

The nearest ground level Fire Service Hydrant (Private Hydrant No. P222 150mm) to the helideck is situated on the Perimeter Road directly opposite to the Dry Riser location adjacent to the ambulance/A&E access road.

data.text: Unforeseen Depletion Of Fire Fighting Media Or Systems

5.23.1 All  unforeseen  depletions  and  non-serviceability  of  helideck  firefighting  systems, equipment, lighting or helideck structural issues that result in temporary closure of the helideck must be reported immediately to:-
The Duty Helideck Fire Officer
Lead Helideck Fire Fighter  Tel Extn No. 5114
Bouygue Helpdesk  Tel Extn No. 6000
Meht Operations Control Centre  Tel Extn Nos. 4512 Or 4666 EoEAS HEMS Desk (CCD)  01245 444496
LAS HEMS Desk   0203 162 7553
Helideck Manager  Tel Extn No. 4205

5.23.2 Firefighting equipment supplied by Bouygue that is taken out of service for repair should be reported / taken to the Bouygue workshop on Level 1, or where purchased by the helideck, returned to the manufacturer for repair or replacement.

5.23.3 Where a fire fighting system failure prevents a continuous delivery of primary media being applied at a minimum rate 250 litres per minute for at least ten minutes the helideck must be declared closed until remedial repairs have been made and/or foam stock levels replenished and the systems fully tested.

5.23.4 Where the minimum quantities of complimentary firefighting agents are not available the helideck must be declared closed until remedial repairs or restocking has been made and the systems fully tested.
Planned / Scheduled Maintenance
5.24.1 Bouygue EFM is responsible for all maintenance and repairs to the helideck structure, firefighting systems and lighting systems.

5.24.2 Helideck and firefighting systems maintenance will normally be undertaken at times outside of the normal helideck hours of operation in liaison with Bouygue and in full accordance with the Broomfield Hospital PFI Project ‘Building Operating & Maintenance Manual FP 3.6a (Fire Protection Services – Helipad Foam/Water System'.
5.24.3 All helideck architectural, mechanical and electrical plans and drawings are kept in the Bouygue Offices, Building Alpha, L1.
5.24.4 All enquiries and requests relating to the maintenance of the helideck structure and firefighting systems will be directed through the Bougue Helpdesk
Bouygue Helpdesk Tel Extn No. 6000
5.24.5 The helideck surface and walkways will be power washed at least annually to remove algae and dirt accumulations.
5.24.6 This task may be carried out by the helideck fire response team in agreement with Bouygue on request.
5.24.7 The helideck perimeter netting is maintained by Bouygue and degradation tests are carried out annually by an external specialist contractor assigned by Bouygue to carry out the work.
Standard Operational Procedures
Daily Opening Of The Helideck
6.1.1 A Helideck Crew Member will be required to open the helideck and ensure equipment serviceability and helideck availability checks are completed no later than 0800 am.

6.1.2 If, for whatever reason, a member of the Helideck Crew is unavailable for duty, for whatever reason, every effort must be made by that person to telephone Helideck Office – Tel No. 01245 513679 or 01245 5114 (Internal Extn Nos. 3679 or 5114) at the earliest opportunity and inform the Senior Helicopter Crew Member/Manager of the expected time of arrival or non-availability.
Helideck operating hours (local time): - Winter: 0800 - half hour after sunset. Summer: 0800 -1600.

6.1.3 It must be appreciated by all helideck staff that no helideck rostered day can be regarded as a 'normal working day' and late calls can be expected on a daily basis extending the working day as necessary.
6.1.4 The helideck fire crew will be required to work a rotating shift pattern as agreed with the Senior Helideck Crew.

6.1.5 The senior helideck staff will have access to the key cabinet and will be responsible for the opening of the helideck offices, crew quarters, helideck access/egress and emergency evacuation routes.

6.1.6 The Senior Helideck Crew will be responsible for opening the Daily Log Book at the beginning of all watch duties and recording all relevant entries throughout the duty period accordingly before closing the log at the end of the watch period.

6.1.7 All helideck fire fighting & medical equipment must be checked daily at the beginning of all watch periods for availability and serviceability and appropriate remarks entered on the Daily Helideck Fire and Medical Equipment Check Sheets and initialled by the person(s) carrying out the check(s).
6.1.8 The on-duty volunteer helideck fire crew maybe required to attend the Helideck Office at 0745 to assist with the helideck opening checks and to receive issue of their pagers.
6.1.9 There are Four volunteer Pagers.
6.1.10 All pagers will be call tested normally a on Tuesday by switchboard.
6.1.11 All helideck staff allocated any of the above pagers are required to respond to the test message accordingly, whether on the helideck or not.
6.1.12 The helideck fire crew will check all hydrants/landing valves, deliveries and lockers are unlocked and prepared in readiness for helideck operations.
6.1.14 The helideck fire crew are to ensure that the in-line Uniductors, hoses and branch pipes are positioned appropriately on both stations ready for immediate use. Hoses are to be 'Dutch' Rolled.
6.1.15 The Wet Riser System should be tested daily by fully opening one landing valve for 60 seconds to ensure a water supply is readily available and that the main pumps are operating.
6.1.16 Ensure FMS is charged (Weather Permitting) and made ready with foam concentrate valves set to OPEN.

6.1.17 Before commencing weekly Helideck Monitor System tests the Helideck Crew Member must ensure that the foam concentrate tank situated below the deck has been isolated in order to produce water only. Only the production of water is required for the weekly test in conjunction with the planned maintenance programme or as part of a planned drill.
6.1.18 The monitor system foam tank should be dipped weekly to confirm foam concentrate levels are in accordance with the system requirements.
6.1.19 On completion of the test the Helideck Crew Member must ensure the foam concentrate inductor valves are set to OPEN.
6.1.20 Visually check ALL portable and hand-held fire extinguishers for availability and serviceability.

6.1.21 The helideck fire crew must carry out a preliminary Foreign Object Debris (FOD) inspection tour on, around and below the helideck and any FOD found removed and placed in the designated FOD bin(s) before declaring the helideck ‘open'.
6.1.22 No other rubbish should be placed in the FOD bins.
6.1.23 All helideck lighting systems including walkway lights must be checked daily before declaring the helideck ‘open'.
6.1.24 Any deficiencies found are to be recorded in the Daily Log and initialled.
6.1.25 Deficiencies that effect the operation and function of the helideck are to be reported immediately to the Senior Helideck Crew Member.

6.1.26 The Senior Helideck Member must inform the MEHT Operations Control Room (Tel Extn No. 4512 or 4666) as soon as practically possible of any deficiency that will affect the safe operation of the helideck.

6.1.27 All fire fighting, medical & ancillary equipment taken out of service for repair should be reported to the appropriate departments, the correct documentation must be completed, or returned to the manufacture for repair or replacement.

6.1.28 The ED and Burns Unit will declare that MEHT is able to receive general emergency patients and phone the helideck office by 0745 (and should also notify the helideck office if circumstances change i.e. closed to blue light admissions etc).

6.1.29 Once all helideck checks have been completed the Senior Helideck Crew Member will be responsible for telephoning the following departments/staff to confirm the helideck is open and fully operational.
Broomfield Operations Centre Tel No. 4512 / 4666
Clinician / Senior Nurse-in-Charge (Burns Intensive Care Unit)
Tel Extn No. 6037 / 6038 BICU
East of England Ambulance Service (EoEAS Air Desk) Tel No. 01245 444496 (Ops and Dispatch)
or
Tel No. 01245 444498 (Duty Manager Operations Centre)
or
Tel No. 01245 444479 (for Extreme Emergency use only)
London Ambulance Service HEMS Desk Tel No 0203 162 7553
Daily Helideck Fire Equipment Check List (Example)

table_items.text: Check & position Resource Cabinet to corridor (inside helideck access doors)
Unlock all fire cabinets and rescue box's
Check and prepare all Fire Fighting Equipment (Nth and Sth Stn + Resource Cabinet)
Check wind direction and select UPWIND Station
Carry out a water delivery test from wet riser – 60 seconds full flow (upwind station)
Set in 1 x hose, branch and inductor into both North and South station landing valves
Ensure grab hooks and ladders are in place and secure at each station
Check 18kg CO2 wheeled fire extinguisher is positioned securely on the ramp
Check 50kg DP wheeled fire extinguisher is positioned securely on the ramp
Check Helideck Lighting (Helideck Green LEDs and corner floods)
Charge FMS system and check foam valves OPEN
Check RPE stowed in Grab Bag on Resource Cabinet Wheel Chocks stowed at Working Station
FOD PLOD (including clearing any bird nests below deck)
Position medical trollies into the corridor
On duty personnel check and prepare PPE and RPE
Issue Volunteer Fire Fighters with Pagers

data.text: Daily Medical Equipment Check List (Example)

table_items.text: Phillips Heartstart AED x 1 Located in Corridor
C / D size Oxygen Cylinder with Regulator and Holder x 2 Check contents gauge min ½ full
F size Oxygen Cylinder with ‘'bull nose'' Regulator x 2 Check contents gauge min ½ full
Self Inflating Resuscitator (bag, valve, mask) x 2

data.text: Strong Wind / Gale / Snow And Ice Safety Procedures
6.4.1 To provide a safe working environment during strong winds and gale situations the following procedures are to be strictly adhered to.
6.4.2 The Broomfield Hospital Helideck will be limited to a maximum wind factor of 40kts constant or gusting from any direction.
6.4.3 The East of England Ambulance Service Air Desk (CCD) and HEMS London must be informed of wind speeds that are likely to effect the safe operation of the helideck.
Tel No. 01245 444496 (EoEAS Ops and Dispatch)
or
Tel No. 01245 444498 (EoEAS Duty Manager Operations Centre)
or
Tel No. 01245 444479 (EoEAS - Extreme Emergency use only)
Tel No. 0203 594 0783 (HEMS London Pilots Office)
Safety Routes To And From North And South Stations
6.5.1 Helicopter On-Deck
Fire crew are to proceed below the deck to the North or South Stations.
They may enter the helideck with caution and must remain well away from the edge of the helideck.
6.5.2 Empty Helideck

Fire crew are to proceed about their business by using the below deck routes only. Under no circumstances are the fire crew to enter the Helideck unless specifically instructed to do so as to carry out a prescribed function.
Snow And Ice Clearing

6.6.1 During periods of actual or expected inclement weather when snow or ice are present or likely to occur, the Senior Helideck Crew Member will inspect the helideck surface and access/egress routes and decide if the application of appropriate ice removing/prevention solutions would allow safe use of the helideck by aircraft and personnel.
6.6.2 The preferred ice clearing/prevention solution should be Killfrost Liquid Ice Melt / GDF.
6.6.3 This is a liquid product, applied by a hand controlled wheeled and 15kg back pack dispensers with applicator lances to provide rapid de-icing
6.6.4 Salt based snow and ice clearing materials must never be used on or around the helideck.
6.6.5 Plastic snow shovels can be used to clear the ‘H' and paths to the access and exit points.
6.6.6 Snow must not be piled on the deck or swept over the side of the helideck where it can fall into the Courtyard or Access Roads.
Call-Out And Pre-Landing Procedures
6.7.1 During operational hours the Helideck Office will normally be manned by at least one of the helideck staff.

6.7.2 The helideck staff will be notified of an impending flight to the helideck by ambulance service or in the case of a crew pick-up request directly by the pilot via the helideck office telephones.
6.7.3 In the case of a burns patient the helideck staff may also be notified by BITU having accepted the patient through consultant referral.

6.7.4 On receiving notification that a HEMS or Air Ambulance service requires to land on the helideck, the helideck duty ops staff will immediately contact Switchboard by pressing the Red Phone ‘Mem 2' with instructions to alert the Helideck Crew (Team
16) to attend the helideck immediately.
6.7.5 Switchboard will immediately alert the duty volunteer helideck fire crew (Team 16) by voice pager using the message “Helideck Crew to helideck immediately”, repeated three times.

6.7.6 On arrival at the Helideck Operations Office, the volunteer helideck fire crew will be allocated their tasks before donning their PPE in readiness to prepare the helideck for all helicopter movements and firefighting duties before going ‘On Deck'.

6.7.7 One member of the helideck fire crew will be assigned to call and secure an appropriate lift car on Level 5 (lift No. 27 or 28), notifying Bouygue Helpdesk (Tel No. 6000) the number of the lift car that has been secured.

6.7.8 The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter must ensure the correct fire standby point is selected and that the helideck fire fighters are in place, standing by for the helicopter arrival. The up-wind station should always be selected whenever possible.
6.7.9 All helideck fire crew are responsible for ensuring that their personal issue RPE is immediately to hand on the designated standby platform.

6.7.10 The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter must ensure that there is no Foreign Object Damage (FOD) on or below the helideck area that could affect the safety of the helicopter, the fire crew, staff or members of the public below.
6.7.11 The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter must ensure that all firefighting systems are correctly set and that the helideck lighting is switched ON.

6.7.12 Broomfield Hospital Emergency Department / A&E and / or the Burns Unit will receive a telephone call from the Ambulance Service Control and / or the HEMS Operator informing them that a HEMS helicopter has been dispatched to the hospital giving an estimated time of arrival (ETA).
6.7.13 When a medical team conduct a ground escort, the pilot may contact the helideck office direct to arrange a crew pick-up from the helideck.
Call Out Procedures Flow Chart
EoEAS  HEMS CONTROL  PILOT
HEMS CREW
ON SCENE  (CCD)
Or
BROOMFIEL BROOMFIEL
D  D HOSPITAL  HELIDECK
Liaise on  FIRE CREW
HOSPITAL  BURNS
Confirmation call to A&E on Red Phone
SWITCHBOARD Helideck Office
PAGE HELIDECK FIRECREW
FIRECREW STANDBY ON HELIDECK TO RECEIVE HEMS
General Roof And Helideck Access Procedures
6.9.1 ABSOLUTELY NO UNAUTHORISED PERSON(S) ARE ALLOWED ON OR BELOW THE HELIDECK OR IMMEDIATE ROOF AREA (Cobbled Area) DURING HELICOPTER OPERATIONS.
6.9.2 This area has been designated as ‘Airside' and is covered by Civil Aviation Authority law.

6.9.3 The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter will ensure all maintenance workers including external contractors working on or in the immediate vicinity of the helideck will be required to stop and secure work and proceed to the nearest helideck exit and standby for permission to re-enter the work area and commence their work.
6.9.4 All MEHT / Bouygue staff / external contractors must book-in and book-out with the Helideck Office before accessing the helideck, roof area adjacent or below the helideck.
6.9.5 No staff will be allowed onto the Deck without being accompanied by MEHT Helideck Fire personnel.
6.9.6 Airside is defined as all areas, above and below the helideck, within the red demarcation line as indicated below.
Helicopter Arrival Procedures
6.10.1 The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter has overall responsibility for the safe and efficient operation of the helideck during helicopter flying operations.

6.10.2 As a member of the dedicated helideck fire crew the primary responsibility is to save life by providing a safe, professional and competent fire protection service and support for the HEMS teams using the helideck in line with the Helideck Manual & Standard Operations Procedures and Health & Safety legislation.
6.10.3 The duty crew shall stand to at least ten minutes prior to the helicopter landing and position to the appropriate pre-selected fire standby station stairwell, remaining below deck level.
6.10.4 ALL personnel protective equipment (PPE) must be worn and correctly donned and RPE made ready for immediate use should it be required.

6.10.5 Approved fire helmets must be worn securely with eye visors in the down position during all landings and departures. Helmets or PPE should not be removed until the aircraft has completely closed down and rotors have stopped.

6.10.6 The helideck crew shall ensure the helideck perimeter lighting (green LED's) are switched ON. This procedure will indicate to the landing helicopter that the helideck is open, available and ready to receive the landing.

6.10.7 Only when the helicopter has landed, shut down and been secured may the helideck crew offer assistance to other members of the HEMS team .The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter or an assigned Helideck fire fighter shall position Wheel Chocks on the main landing gear (wheeled helicopters only) and position the CO2 fire extinguisher appropriately.

6.10.8 The duty helideck fire crew must not approach the helicopter before receiving a positive 'thumbs up' from the captain or unless the aircraft is completely closed down with rotors stopped and all navigation lights / strobes off. This will be supervised by The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter.
6.10.9 Under no circumstances should any member of the helideck fire crew go under the helicopter main rotor blades during the start up or shut down cycles due to the dangers of ‘blade sail'.
6.10.10 One designated fire fighter will be responsible for manoeuvring the medical trolley on to helideck under supervision of The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter.

6.10.11 The off-loading of the casualty is normally controlled and undertaken by the HEMS flight crew / medical crew. Helideck Crew Members will make them Selves-available to assist with the patient handling under the instruction of the medical team as required but only in accordance with the training they have received.
6.10.12 FC5 will assist and escort the medical team to the designated lift on Level 5 and the transfer of the patient to the appropriate receiving unit.

6.10.13 Unless an immediate return to the helideck is required the Helideck Crew Member will remain with the HEMS team in order to retrieve all helideck medical equipment and the dedicated helideck medical trolley used by the HEMS team during the transfer.
6.10.14 The Helideck Crew will be available to assist and escort the HEMS team back to the helideck

6.10.15 Following the departure and fire crew stand down the Crew Member who called the lift will be responsible for notifying the Bouygue Helpdesk (Tel No. 6000) that the secured lift has been released back in to general service.
Helicopter Departure Procedures
6.11.1 All helideck fire crew will proceed in full PPE to the designated helideck platform standby point.

6.11.2 The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter will stand well outside of the rotor disc at the twelve o'clock position to the nose of the aircraft and where eye to eye contact can be maintained with the pilot and also where both engine starts can be monitored.
6.11.3 A member of the helideck fire crew will standby with the mobile CO2 extinguisher in preparation for and during engine start-up and be ready to commence fire fighting duties.
6.11.4 Once both engines are running safely the pilot should signal that he is ready for take-off by giving a positive ‘thumbs up' to The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter.
6.11.5 The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter will then ask the on-deck fire fighter to remove the mobile CO2 extinguisher from the helideck and stow accordingly.
6.11.6 All helideck fire crew to vacate the helideck and position to the pre-selected standby station or as directed by The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter.

6.11.7 The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter will carry out a final check that aircraft doors and panels are secure before vacating the helideck to the designated standby station in readiness for the helicopter departure.
6.11.8 The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter will then confirm by giving a positive 'thumbs up' to the pilot that the aircraft is safe to depart.

6.11.9 If for any reason it is deemed the helicopter is NOT safe to depart, The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter must attempt to attract the pilots attention by hand waves or making themselves visible to the pilot giving a positive ‘thumbs down'.
6.11.10 At no stage should any member of the helideck fire response team put themselves in a place of danger.
6.11.11 Ensure there is no ambiguity regarding hand signals. The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter is only to approach the helicopter after receiving a positive ‘thumbs up' from the pilot.
6.11.12 The pilot may try to communicate with the Lead Helideck Fire Fighter through an open door or window. Due to the high noise levels this is often very difficult to achieve.
6.11.13 After the helicopter has departed the helideck fire response team are to remain at full readiness for at least a further full five minutes.
End Of Flying Operations And Closing The Helideck
6.12.1 All lockers, deliveries and hydrants are to remain open for at least FIVE MINUTES after the last helicopter departure of the day.

6.12.2 The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter will be responsible for ensuring ALL fire fighting AND medical equipment are securely locked away and that ALL deliveries and hydrants are secured before closing the helideck.
6.12.3 Ensure the FMS drained down.
6.12.4 Ensure all helideck lighting is switched OFF.
6.12.5 The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter will telephone the following to confirm the helideck is closed.
MEHT Operations Centre Tel No. 4512 / 4666
Clinician / Senior Nurse-in-Charge (Burns Intensive Care Unit) Tel Extn No. 6037 / 6038 BICU
East of England Ambulance Service (EoEAS Air Desk) Tel No. 01245 444496 (Ops and Dispatch)
or
Tel No. 01245 444498 (Duty Manager Operations Centre)
or
Tel No. 01245 444479 (for Extreme Emergency use only)
Note: There is no requirement to notify the LAS HEMS Desk when closing.
Office Security
6.13.1 The Senior Helideck Officer(s) will ensure that the correct entries have been made in the Daily Occurrence Log before closing the log.
6.13.2 Before leaving, the fire crew will ensure that all office doors and windows are secure and that all fire exit doors from the helideck are locked.
Helicopter Marshalling
6.14.1 Helicopter marshalling signals must not be given or attempted by any untrained or non-qualified persons under any circumstances.

6.14.2 The only exceptions to this rule shall be in the event that the helideck fire crew deem that it is unsafe for a helicopter to land for whatever reason or to signal a fire warning to the flight crew.
Wave Off

6.15.1 The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter is to position to the centre of the deck with both arms raised vertically above the head, lowering both arms to the horizontal repeatedly whilst crossing the arms in the vertical. This signal is recognised internationally as a ‘wave off'.
6.15.2 At no stage shall The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter put themselves in a position of danger by remaining on the deck.
Fire

6.16.1 The ICAO international hand signal to indicate an aircraft fire is to produce a repeated horizontal figure of eight signal using the right hand in front of the body while pointing at the source of fire with the left hand. This signal should be aimed at the flight crew.
6.16.2 Any helideck fire crew member can initiate this signal in the event of an aircraft fire.
Radio Procedures
6.17.1 For general purpose communications between firecrew and/or Helideck Operations, Motorola DP4000 hand held radios are available from the helideck office.
6.17.2 These radios are to be set to Channel 1 for helideck communications and are not chipped for aviation useage. Channel 1 is also a shared frequency with Portering Services.
Lift Operating Procedures
6.18.1 ALL helideck fire crew are required to carry their identity/swipe card on them at all times when covering helideck duties
6.18.2 The lift control keys with attached security door swipe cards (Key Fob 6 & 7) are held in the secure key cabinet in the Helideck Office.
6.18.3 The preferred lifts for helideck patient transfer use are:-
Lift No. 27 4 LH situated at the east end of the Level 5 corridor Lift No. 28 4 RH situated at the east end of the Level 5 corridor
For bariatric patients it may be preferred to use lifts: -
Lift No. 25 3 LH situated midway along the Level 5 corridor Lift No. 26 3 RH situated midway along the Level 5 corridor
6.18.4 A Crew Member will proceed to the appropriate lift lobby and call a lift to L5.
6.18.5 The Crew Member will enter lift and insert key into the ‘Car Preference' key lock and turn key until the key lock is illuminated by a red back light. Remove key from the locked position.
6.18.6 Insert key into the ‘Door Hold' key lock and turn until the key lock is illuminated by a red back light. Remove key from the locked position and retain.
6.18.7 Press L2 call button to pre-set lift ready to descend to L2 for Rescue / A&E / Burns
6.18.8 ensuring required level call button is illuminated.
6.18.9 Place ‘Helicopter Lift Only – Do Not Use' barrier in front of lift.
6.18.10 Make note of the Lift No. which can be found on the plaque above the call buttons inside the lift.

6.18.11 On securing the lift on Level 5, contact the Bouygue Helpdesk (Tel. extn 6000) to inform that Lift No. ** * ** is locked onto the 5th floor for helideck use only using the internal use telephone in the corridor or office telephone.
6.18.12 Patient Transfer. All persons enter lift with patient stretcher.
6.18.13 Place retained lift key into ‘Door Hold' and switch to OFF and leave key in switch.
6.18.14 Lift doors will close and lift will descend to L2 as pre-set.
6.18.15 At L2 doors will open, medical team will remove patient and vacate lift. The Crew Member must lock ‘Door Hold' to ON and pre-set lift to return to L5. Remove key and retain.
6.18.16 Place ‘Helicopter Lift Only – Do Not Use' barrier in front of lift.
6.18.17 Returning to L5. Remove barrier and enter lift. Place key into ‘Doors Open' switch and turn to OFF. Remove key and retain.
6.18.18 Lift doors will close and ascend to pre-set L5.
6.18.19 On L5 use lift key to switch ‘Car Preference' to off before vacating lift. Red back light will extinguish. Remove key and retain.
6.18.20 Inform Bouygue Helpdesk (Tel extn 6000) that lift has been returned for general use.
6.18.21 Lift key and security door swipe card must be returned to key cabinet in the Helideck Office
Broomfield Helideck Helicopter Overdue Action Procedure

6.19.1 Broomfield Hospital Emergency Department / A&E and / or the Burns Unit will receive a telephone call from the Ambulance Service Control and / or the HEMS Operator informing them that a HEMS helicopter has been dispatched to the hospital giving an Estimated Time of Arrival (ETA).
6.19.2 Broomfield Hospital Emergency Department / A&E and / or the Burns Unit will pass the in-bound mission details and ETA to the Helideck Office.
6.19.3 Ambulance Service Control and the HEMS Operator will co-ordinate and follow the mission by established communications with the medical team and flight crew
6.19.4 Broomfield Helideck Overdue Action Procedures will come into effect if the helicopter is 30 minutes late and no communications with the helicopter team have been received.
6.19.5 The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter will be responsible for telephoning the following to notify the helicopter is overdue.
East of England Ambulance Service (EoEAS Air Desk) Tel No. 01245 444496 (Ops and Dispatch)
or
Tel No. 01245 444498 (Duty Manager Operations Centre)
or
Tel No. 01245 444479 (for absolute Emergency use only)
Emergency Orders
Helideck Emergency Orders

7.1.1 The objective of Emergency Orders is to determine that the correct response(s) by external agencies and/or in-house support services are appropriate to manage any helideck emergency or untoward incident.

7.1.2 The Broomfield Hospital helideck operates by best practice to 'Permanently Unlicensed H1 Elevated Helideck' in accordance with CAP437, CAP789 and Department of Health publication HBN15-03 THIS HBN15-03 DOCUMENT HAS BEEN SUPERSDED BY CAP1264 – Hospital Helipads and accordingly will have a helideck trained RFFS standing-by in full readiness to deal effectively and competently with any emergency on or within the immediate vicinity of the helideck.
Designated Response Area
7.2.1 The designated response area for the Helideck Fire Crew is defined as the immediate area of the helideck platform and the cobbled roof area below and adjacent to the helideck.
7.2.2 The helideck fire crew are not trained or competent to deal with any domestic fires or fires involving any internal part of the building.
Categories Of Helideck Emergencies
7.3.1  The likely emergencies to occur on or within the vicinity of the helideck involving a helicopter will include Aircraft Accident
Full Emergency (or In-flight Emergency)
Ground Incident
Medical Emergency
Aircraft Accident
7.4.1 An aircraft accident classifies an accident which has either occurred, or which is inevitable on, or in the vicinity of the helideck.
7.4.2 An aircraft accident would invariably call for an immediate response by the helideck fire crew and local authority emergency services and other agencies.
Full Emergency (Or In-Flight Emergency)
7.5.1 A full emergency is the correct classification “When it is known that an aircraft is, or is suspected to be, in such trouble that there is a danger of an accident”

7.5.2 If an in-flight emergency occurs the helicopter will only attempt to land onto the helideck if the emergency has occurred during take-off before the Critical Decision Point (CPD) has been reached or during the landing-on phase if the helicopter has passed the Landing Decision Point (LDP).
7.5.3 It will be the responsibility of the aircrew flying the helicopter to make these decisions in-line with their helicopter performance values.
7.5.4 At all other times if an in-flight emergency occurs, the helicopter will divert to the nearest airfield or make an emergency landing into a surface level open space.
7.5.5 Out of control engine fires (during start up or shut down sequence) and/or cabin fires will be declared as a Full Emergency.
Ground Incident

7.6.1 A Ground Incident is defined as being one where an aircraft on the ground is known to have an emergency situation other than an accident, requiring an immediate response from the helideck fire crew and possibly external emergency services.

7.6.2 It is important that what constitutes a “Ground Incident” is thoroughly understood by all involved. Generally a “Ground Incident” on the helideck will involve technical faults or minor collision damage either by the helicopter clipping an obstruction but landing safely or an object striking the helicopter while on the helideck.
7.6.3 If the collision is such that damage results in fire or injuries this type of incident may well develop quickly into an Aircraft Accident.

7.6.4 The correct classification is essential as invariably different levels of response by external agencies and emergency services will apply depending on the classification given at the time of call.
Local Standby and Weather Standby
7.7.1  Due to the fact that the Helideck Fire Response Team will standby for all helicopter movements therefore there is no requirement for Local Standby or Weather Standby procedures.
Medical Emergency
7.8.1 The hospital provides a dedicated medical emergency response team for cardiac arrest and trauma.
7.8.2 The emergency Cardiac Arrest / Fire / Security telephone number is Dedicated Red Phone - Memory 2
7.8.3 The helideck fire crew will be required to be trained to Basic Life Support (BLS) standard. (minimum) & Basic First Aid
7.8.4 All declared Aircraft Accident or Full Emergency incidents require the immediate response from external fire and ambulance services.
Command And Control At A Helicopter Incident
7.9.1 In order to establish Incident Command and Control at an aircraft accident site there is a need to establish a zoning system around the incident.

7.9.2 Airport fire services and local fire service authorities have agreed to the following zones being established after dynamic risk assessments immediately following an incident, and will need to take into account the location of the crash site, any building damage that may affect the zone location, wind direction and from where communications can be established with the Hospital Major Incident Room and other agencies.
7.9.3 ZONE 1 – The accident site(s) where the helicopter and wreckage are situated within which fire services will operate in order to establish control of any fire and effect rescue.

7.9.4 Only the minimum number of authorised emergency services personnel will be allowed to work in this zone for the purpose of saving life and property which can be saved. Absolutely no other unauthorised personnel are allowed into Zone 1 due to the hazards that will be present.

7.9.5 Zone 1 will be initially under the command of The Helideck Fire Officer / Lead Helideck Fire Fighter (Bronze) until command of the incident can be safely passed to a more senior local authority fire officer.
7.9.6 ZONE 2 – Is designated the Casualty Evacuation and Clearance Zone.
7.9.7 It is within this zone, which will be situated in a safe area outside of Zone 1, that casualties will be evacuated to and immediate treatment and stabilisation will take place.
7.9.8 ZONE 3 – Is generally designated the Ambulance Loading Point, where casualties can be transported from to A&E.

7.9.9 Other zones may need to be established if wreckage and casualties are found in other areas. These areas will be under the command of the local authority fire service and ambulance service accordingly.
7.9.10 An Incident Control Point should be established adjacent to Zone 1 and Zone 2 where the local authority Incident Control Officer will exercise overall control of the incident.
7.9.11 The Incident Control Officer will require communications to Zone 1, 2 and 3, the Hospital Major Incident Room.
Helideck Incident Response Procedures

7.10.1 Should an incident occur on the helideck the Helideck Fire Alarm must be activated immediately by the Helideck Fire Team to alert Switchboard and put into action and entrain the Broomfield Hospital Standard Fire Procedures.
7.10.2 The helideck is equipped with 4 x fire alarm activation call points (Zone 145) linked to an auto-dialler service and to switchboard in the event of a helideck emergency
North West Station platform.
South East Station platform.
Outside wall by the main helideck access door from Level 5 corridor.
Adjacent to south side air handling units, positioned on corner handrail overlooking the inner court yard area.
7.10.3 On activation of fire alarm from Zone 145, Switchboard will contact Fire Service and confirm >>>>>>>>

7.10.4 The helideck fire crew will attempt to control and extinguish any fires on the helideck or roof area using the designated helideck firefighting systems and equipment and provide humanitarian assistance to self-rescuing survivors and trapped casualties until assistance arrives from the emergency services.
7.10.5 Emergency exits routes from the helideck platform are situated at the south-east corner, north-west corner and the ramp.
7.10.6 Below the helideck roof area are paved pathways leading to exit doors onto the Level 5 corridor or across the roof area.

7.10.7 Local Authority Fire & Rescue Services will be met at the roundabout at the top of Hospital Approach by a porter/security staff and directed left around the Perimeter Road towards the helideck location situated on the south side of the site.
7.10.8 The RVP for Local Authority Fire & Rescue Services is the South Perimeter Road.
7.10.9 For the Local Authority Fire & Rescue Services Pre-Determined Attendance (PDA) for a helideck incident see Section 6, Appendix
7.10.10 The first pump in attendance should set into the helideck wet riser situated below the helideck and supplement their supply from H1 marked on the LAFS SSRI (See Appendix 5 at back of SOP).
7.10.11 A LAFS Junior Officer should make their way to the 5th floor to liaise with the Helideck Fire Officer / The Lead Helideck Fire Fighter.
7.10.12 The helideck access doors from the L5 corridor are NOT locked during helicopter operations.
7.10.13 The LAFS OiC should remain on the ground floor.
7.10.14 The second pump in attendance is to set into the dry riser situated at >>>>>> and supplement their supply from H2.
7.10.15 LAFS crews to take all available foam up to helideck.

7.10.16 Security staff, Hospital Fire Marshalls or any other member of staff designated to respond to the fire alarm activation in accordance with the Trust's Fire Safety Policy, Fire Evacuation Policy and other local fire plans and procedures (covered by MEHT mandatory training), must not enter the helicopter incident area (ZONE 1) unless authorised to do so by the Senior Helideck Officers and only with appropriately donned PPE and RPE.
Helideck Emergency Responsibilities
7.11.1 The Helideck Fire Response Team
The helideck fire response team will respond immediately to any helideck incident in accordance with the Helideck Standard Operating Procedures and the training they have received.

The CAA recommends that response times for an incident involving a helicopter on an elevated helipad / helideck should be no more than  seconds from the incident occurring to activation of the primary firefighting systems for the production of foam at the required application rate and a further 30 seconds to bring a fire associated with a helicopter incident to be brought under control* in optimum conditions (Helideck Response Time – 45 seconds).
*Under control is assumed to be the point when it becomes possible for occupants of the helicopter to be effectively rescued, not the time that all fires are extinguished (CAP 789 12.3).
7.11.2 The Senior Helideck Officers (Bronze)

The Helideck Fire Officer / Lead Helideck Fire Fighter will ensure the Helideck Fire Alarm System has been activated and take command of all helideck incidents until such time a senior fire officer from the local authority fire services is able to take overall command of the incident on handover.

The Helideck Fire Officer / Lead Helideck Fire Fighter will be the point of contact and liaison for local emergency services, excluding the early stages of the incident, and  will  be  available  to provide  specialist  advice  regarding  the  incident  at  the earliest opportunity.

As soon as practically possible The Helideck Fire Officer / Lead Helideck Fire Fighter will provide Bronze Command liaison duties at the incident area (Zone 1 until relived by the Local Authority Incident Command Officer who will then take over the role of BRONZE.
7.11.3 Broomfield Hospital Porters, Security And Fire Marshalls
A member of Porter/Security staff will be tasked to meet the fire service at the roundabout at the top of Hospital Approach and direct them to the helideck.

Security staff, Hospital Fire Marshalls and any other member of staff designated to respond to the fire alarm activation in accordance with the Trust's Fire Safety Policy, Fire Evacuation Policy and other local fire plans and procedures (covered by Broomfield mandatory training), must not enter the helicopter incident area (ZONE 1) unless authorised to do so by Helideck The Helideck Fire Officer / Lead Fire Fighter and only with appropriately donned PPE and RPE.

Local Fire Procedures Not Involving The Helideck
MEHT applies and strictly enforces a No Smoking policy within any building on site. GENERAL HOSPITAL FIRE PROCEDURES FOR ZONE ‘A' L5
THE HELIDECK OFFICES AND ON-CALL CORRIDOR
FOR FIRE
Activate fire alarm call point
Call Tel No. 2999
Report your name and location
Close windows and doors (do not lock)
Tackle fire only if it is safe to do so, using the correct fire extinguisher for class of fire involved
GENERAL EVACUATION PROCEDURES FOR ZONE ‘A' L5 THE HELIDECK OFFICES AND ON-CALL CORRIDOR
Switch off non-essential electrical apparatus
Evacuate area immediately – Do not run.
Report to the Evacuation Assembly Point situated outside of Zone ‘A' West Entrance - at the Chemo Therapy and Renal Unit ‘drop-off point'.
Environmental Considerations

7.14.1 The helideck surface area is protected by a 360° dedicated drainage system designed to collect natural day-to-day run-off and contaminated run-off including aviation fuels and oils, which could be on fire.
7.14.2 The drainage gulley is linked to 10 vertical stack pipes that run below the helideck converging into 4 main stack pipes before entering the building structure through the roof of L4.
7.14.3 Each of the four main pipes is fitted with a non-return valve designed to exclude oxygen entry in the event of fire.

7.14.4 The waste down pipes fall through the building within a mechanical riser to ground level where the pipe exits the building and connects to a dedicated, bunded Waste Water / Pollutant Interceptor tank before discharging into the site waste drain.
7.14.5 This interceptor tank has a nominal capacity of 11,000 litre filtered capacity.
7.14.6 The interceptor tank is designed to collect 10,000 litres of water and can separate off 1,000 litres of contaminated liquids.
7.14.7 Within  the  interceptor  system  is  an  alarm  system  that  will  activate  and  alert Bouygue that the interceptor is nearing full and must be emptied at the earliest opportunity.
Training Requirements
The training requirements are outlined in the RFFS Training Manual.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Health and Safety Management Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and procedures. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Health and safety Managemnt group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

The Helideck Manager / Lead Helideck Fire Fighter and Helideck Fire Officer shall be responsible  for  identifying  and  producing  any  amendments  to  this  manual  in conjunction with the Trust Senior Hospital Fire Officer.
Advise will be obtained from Independent and External Auditor when required.
The SOPs will be reviewed annually.
The Change Management Process for this document is as follows:
